awd_titl_txt: Friction and plasticity of amorphous metal coatings
awd_abstract_narration:
The research objective of this grant is to elucidate the fundamental mechanisms of friction and plasticity in amorphous metal coatings.  Certain MEMS/NEMS devices operated in dynamic mode have long been haunted by tribological issues.  The scale-down of devices leads to large increases in surface force, including friction.  In miniaturized gears manufactured by electrodeposited nanocrystalline metal, wear becomes an important issue.  Environmental issues associated with electrodeposition of hard Cr coatings also call for commensurate replacement that can be fabricated by environment benign process.  High-strength, amorphous metal coating is an appealing candidate for these purposes as it has high hardness, low surface roughness, and compatible elastic modulus and thermal expansion coefficient in comparison to metal substrates.  However its friction behavior is poorly understood.  Plasticity in amorphous coatings is an equally important subject, as it directly impacts tribological properties of these coatings.  Several hypotheses will be tested, including amorphous metal coatings may have much lower friction coefficient than their crystalline counterparts, layer interface may induce unique friction and wear properties in amorphous multilayers.  To examine these hypotheses, the PI will combine nanofabrication of amorphous films with advanced friction and nanomechanical testing techniques.

If successful, the project may significantly improve the reliability and functionality of NEMS/MEMS components, magnetic data storage devices and wear resistant coatings.  The concept and knowledge derived from this project will be of great scientific interest to metallic glass, coatings, nanomechanics, NEMS/MEMS, and the tribology community.  Additionally this project will offer research training to graduate and undergraduate students at Texas A & M University (TAMU).  Special effort will be made to recruit female and other minority students through the "Pathway to Ph.D program" funded by TAMU.  The project will also enhance the materials science and nanoengineering curricula by incorporating the relevant results into classes when introducing advanced nanomaterials and benefit the relatively new Materials Science and Engineering graduate program.  The PI will disseminate results to a much broader audience by involving high school teachers in the research project through NSF-RET program and through participation in international conferences.  Collaborations with national laboratories will offer graduate students summer research experiences.
org_div_long_name: Division of Civil, Mechanical, and Manufacturing Innovation

por.por_cntn:
The objective of this proposal is to understand, at a fundamental level, the mechanisms of friction and plasticity in amorphous metal coatings. There are several hypotheses to be tested. (1) In comparison to crystalline counterparts, amorphous metal coatings may have much lower friction coefficient, and a very different film thickness dependent friction behavior. (2) Layer interface may induce unique friction and wear properties in amorphous multilayers. (3) Multilayer interfaces may impart plasticity in amorphous metals by promoting shear delocalization. To examine these hypotheses, the PI’s group has combined nanofabrication of amorphous multilayers films with advanced friction and nanomechanical testing techniques, including in situ nanoindentation technique inside a transmission electron microscope and in situ tensile tests in a scanning electron microscope.

Intellectual merit. The major scientific findings of this project can be summarized briefly as follows. (1) Observed ultra-low stress induced nanocrystallization in amorphous Cu-Zr-Al alloy at ultra-low stress as evidenced by in situ nanoindentation in TEM. (2) Discovered Unusual size dependent strengthening of crystalline Cu/amorphous CuNb multilayers by experiment and molecular dynamics simulations. (3) Discovered shear delocalization of crystalline Cu/amorphous CuNb multilayers under tension as shown by ductile dimples on fracture surface. (4) The study shows that fracture behaviors of architectured crystalline/amorphous multilayers can be tuned by changing the volume fraction and layer thickness of the layers. (5) Developed a model to account for the layer thickness dependent strain rate sensitivity of crystalline/amorphous multilayers. (8) Investigated the friction behaviors of crystalline/amorphous multilayers as a function of layer thickness.

Broader impact. (a) Outreach to scientific community. During this project, we collaborated with scientists from Los Alamos National Laboratory, Argonne National Laboratory, Rice University, University of Nebraska, Lincoln. (b) Dissemination of results to broader audience. The PI’s team has hosted numerous undergraduate students and high school teachers in consecutive years and involved them in this project. (c) Professional preparation for students. 2 Ph.D. students were directly involved in this project. They have now become postdocs at DOE National Laboratory. (e) Research outcome. 9 articles were published in peer-reviewed scientific journals (plus 2 more in preparation). Numerous invited talks were presented at national and international conferences and national laboratories. 

 


Last Modified: 10/13/2017
Modified by: Xinghang Zhang

Image
  • Tensile studies show that fracture surface of Cu/amorphous CuNb has ductile dimples.
    Zhe Fan
    Copyrighted
    Xinghang Zhang
    Ductile fracture surface in amorphous metals
